Gobierno cubano impide viajar a periodista independiente
03 Nov 2019, 20:51 by Lázaro Javier Chirino
La periodista independiente Camila Acosta ingresa a la lista de regulados que el Gobierno de Cuba impide salir de la isla. Así lo ha denunciado ella misma en sus redes sociales desde La Habana, luego de que no pudiera abordar el avión que la llevaría a un evento en Argentina.
“Comienzan las consecuencias de las que me advirtieron los segurosos”, escribió en Twitter usando también la etiqueta #Ni1ReguladoMás.



En contacto con CiberCuba, la periodista contó que viajaría a Buenos Aires invitada por el Centro para la Apertura y el Desarrollo de América Latina (CADAL), para participar en el programa llamado Good bye, Lenin y realizar la cobertura electoral del balotaje en Uruguay.
Al llegar al aeropuerto y entregar su pasaporte y boleto de viaje le notificaron que ellos, como funcionarios de la Aduana, no sabían los motivos de su regulación, solo que aparecía en un listado y no podía salir del país.
Acerca de las amenazas que había recibido con anterioridad, Acosta relató que el pasado miércoles, a su regreso de un viaje a Estados Unidos, dos oficiales de la Seguridad del Estado que se identificaron como Iván y Osvaldo la interrogaron en el aeropuerto de La Habana y le decomisaron libros, folletos y una gorra aludiendo que eran “propaganda subversiva”, 
En el interrogatorio le advirtieron que “iba a comenzar a sentir el peso de las consecuencias por ser activista de DD.HH. y periodista independiente”, cuenta Camila y agrega: “esto lo venía venir”.
Es la primera vez que Acosta se ve envuelta en esta situación. El pasado 4 de octubre se presentó en su casa un agente que se identificó como Ernesto y la amenazó con que no realizaría el viaje a Estados Unidos.“Yo hice caso omiso a su amenaza y fui al aeropuerto”, explica y asegura que se sorprendió mucho cuando la dejaron salir. “Pero esta vez sí me pusieron en la lista de regulados”, agrega.



Le preguntamos qué haría ahora que sabe que no puede salir de la isla y explicó que buscará un abogado para hacer la denuncia. “Sé que no van a dar respuesta alguna porque nunca la han dado, pero al menos ir por sus propios mecanismos legales. Después... veremos”, expresó.
El Instituto Patmos, encargado de llevar el conteo de cubanos regulados por las autoridades cubanas e impedidos de salir de la isla, hasta el 1 de noviembre calculaba un total de 199 personas bajo este concepto. Por tanto, Camila Acosta es la persona número 200 a la que el Gobierno de La Habana impide salir de Cuba y que convierte en cárcel al territorio insular.

Cuban government prevents travel to independent journalist
03 Nov 2019, 20:51 by Lázaro Javier Chirino
The independent journalist Camila Acosta enters the list of regulated that the Government of Cuba prevents from leaving the island. She has denounced this in her social networks from Havana, after she could not board the plane that would take her to an event in Argentina.
"The consequences of what the insurance companies warned me begin," he wrote on Twitter using the # Ni1ReguladoMás tag.



In contact with CiberCuba, the journalist said that she would travel to Buenos Aires invited by the Center for the Opening and Development of Latin America (CADAL), to participate in the program called Good bye, Lenin and to carry out the electoral coverage of the ballot in Uruguay.
Upon arriving at the airport and delivering his passport and travel ticket, he was notified that they, as Customs officials, did not know the reasons for their regulation, only that it appeared on a list and could not leave the country.
Regarding the threats he had previously received, Acosta said that on Wednesday, on his return from a trip to the United States, two State Security officers who identified themselves as Iván and Osvaldo interrogated her at the Havana airport and they confiscated books, brochures and a cap, referring to “subversive propaganda,”
During the interrogation, he was warned that "he was going to begin to feel the weight of the consequences of being a human rights activist and independent journalist," Camila says and adds: "This was coming."
It is the first time that Acosta is involved in this situation. On October 4, an agent who identified himself as Ernesto appeared at his home and threatened that he would not make the trip to the United States. "I ignored his threat and went to the airport," he explains and assures that he was surprised a lot when they let her out. "But this time they put me on the regulated list," he adds.



We asked him what he would do now that he knows he cannot leave the island and explained that he will seek a lawyer to make the complaint. “I know that they will not give any answer because they have never given it, but at least go by their own legal mechanisms. Then ... we'll see, ”he said.
The Patmos Institute, in charge of keeping the count of Cubans regulated by the Cuban authorities and prevented from leaving the island, until November 1 calculated a total of 199 people under this concept. Therefore, Camila Acosta is the 200th person that the Government of Havana prevents from leaving Cuba and that turns the island territory into jail.
